meanings.definition: To remove a crown from someone's head.
meanings.sent1: The king decided to uncrown himself and give the crown to his daughter.
meanings.sent2: The queen had to uncrown the prince in order to place the crown on the new king's head.
meanings.sent3: The jester tried to uncrown the king as a prank, but he quickly realized it was a bad idea.
meanings.sent4: The storm's strong winds seemed to uncrown the trees, leaving them bare and vulnerable.
meanings.sent5: The magician's trick was to uncrown the volunteer from the audience, leaving everyone amazed.

meanings.definition: To deprive someone of royal status or authority.
meanings.sent1: The revolution aimed to uncrown the tyrant and establish a new government.
meanings.sent2: The council decided to uncrown the corrupt nobleman and strip him of all his titles.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous court jester joked that he would uncrown the queen and become ruler himself.
meanings.sent4: The scandal threatened to uncrown the once-respected leader, tarnishing his reputation irreparably.
meanings.sent5: The unexpected defeat seemed to uncrown the champion, shocking the spectators.
